poem:
### Bacon's Allure

From the belly's stretch,  
a tapestry of smoke rises—  
mahogany, crisp,  
the scent weaving tales  
in air that's thick with history.  
Layers of taste speak  
in tongues ancient and elemental,  
as morning assembles  
around God's humble altar—  
the sizzle, a hymn,  
each rasher, a sermon  
in the house of hunger.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Crisps up perfectly’: the best (and worst) supermarket bacon, tasted and rated Crisp, mahogany-red rashers of smoked streaky bacon are the food of the gods. Naturally rich in glutamates – umami compounds that make food deeply savoury – it’s no wonder that the smell of sizzling bacon has such legendary allure. As the name suggests, layers of fat are marbled through a rasher of streaky bacon, which comes from the lower belly of the pig.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
